name: Letter from Clusius, Carolus to Lipsius, Justus, 1591-09-30

Diplomatic.text: Iusto Lipsio Car[olus] Clusius S[alutem] D[icit]. Gratissimum fuit intelligere, mi Lipsi, tuam valetudinem satis tolerabilem esse eiusque firmandae causa Spadam iterum cogitare; sed vereor ut aptus sit autumnus qui frigidior esse solet. Quod frueris fine illo consilii tui gaudeo nec otiosum te futurum satis scio. Velim aedes istic nancisci possis ex animi tui sententia et quae hortum habent in quem transferas tuas delicias. Caniculares dies fuerunt hic permadidi multosque bulbos mihi corruperunt, praesertim e selectioribus tulipis, ut vix habuerim unde meorum aulaeorum lacunas explerem. Mitto tamen aliquot tulipas semine selectiorum natas et aliquot bulbos stirpesque tuberosas elegantiores. Addidi etiam semina non vulgaria, ut e plantis inde natis aliquando voluptatem capere possis. Quas meis adiunxeras diligenter curavi et binas ad te mitto, his nundinis mihi redditas. Colvius frustratus fuit sua spe, de qua apud omnes gloriabatur et etiam ad parentes scripserat; alius locum quem sperabat, occupavit; locum tamen apud fratrem eius, cui a secretis esse cogitabat, tandem obtinuit et cum exercitu abiit, sed non tam honeste ab suo hospite discessit quam decebat et nostrae nationi maculam inussit. Brederodius multum salutem tibi renuntiat, Bongarsius, Sylburgius, Cassiodorus, qui vellet hic diutius haesisses, ego sane prae ceteris. Bene vale. Salutem dico Cl[arissimo] V[iro] Lampsonio, qui mihi notus initio anni LXIII cum isthac cum Sambuco facerem iter, Augustam Vindelicorum tendens. Francofurti, XX Sept[embris] veteris calculi XCI. [Address:] Clariss[imo] Viro, D[omi]n[o] Iusto Lipsio, amico singulari. Leodium.

Cassiodorus:
Cassiodorus Reinius (de Reyn), a Lutheran theologian originating from Seville († Frankfurt, 15 March 1594). After renouncing Catholicism, he settled in Frankfurt a/M. and engaged himself in the silk trade. He acted as a preacher for the Walloon congregation in London, was called as minister to the Walloon congregation in Antwerp, but soon afterwards driven away. He resumed his previous activities in Frankfurt until 1593, when he became minister of the Dutch Walloon congregation. He translated Johannes Seranus’s history of France from French into Latin, and the whole Bible into Spanish. Cf. Jöcher 3, 2039.

annotations.text:
initio anni LXIII:
Thanks to a recommendation by Johann Crato von Krafftheim Clusius had been commissioned in August 1563 to accompany Johann and Marcus Fugger from Augsburg on their peregrinatio academica. Still in August he went to Augsburg and returned to Antwerp in October. After a short sojourn in Ghent he went to Southern France and Spain together with the Fuggers at the beginning of 1564, cf. Biographie nationale 5, 388.

permadidi:
A neologism, not attested in the Latin from Antiquity nor in Hoven - Grailet, Lexique de la prose latine de la Renaissance.

aulaeorum:
Aulaeum, a transcription from the Greek, (carpet, curtain) and usually poetical in Latin, is here used in a figurative sense, namely a flowerbed.
Colvius:Colvius probably expected to become secretary to Turenne. According to Aa 3, 635 he became secretary to one of the French ambassadors in the German Empire.
